skll Package¶

skll Package¶

This package provides a number of utilities to make it simpler to run common scikit-learn experiments with pre-generated features.

author:Dan Blanchard (dblanchard@ets.org)
author:Michael Heilman (mheilman@ets.org)
author:Nitin Madnani (nmadnani@ets.org)
organization:ETS
class skll.__init__.Learner(probability=False, do_scale_features=False, model_type=u'logistic', model_kwargs=None, pos_label_str=None, use_dense_features=False, min_feature_count=1)¶

Bases: object

A simpler learner interface around many scikit-learn classification and regression functions.

Parameters:
  • do_scale_features (bool) – Should we scale features with this learner?
  • model_type (basestring) – Type of estimator to create. Options are: ‘logistic’, ‘svm_linear’, ‘svm_radial’, ‘naivebayes’, ‘dtree’, ‘rforest’, and ‘gradient’
  • probability (bool) – Should learner return probabilities of all classes (instead of just class with highest probability)?
  • model_kwargs (dict) – A dictionary of keyword arguments to pass to the initializer for the specified model.
  • pos_label_str (str) – The string for the positive class in the binary classification setting. Otherwise, an arbitrary class is picked.
  • use_dense_features (bool) – Whether to require conversion to dense feature matrices.
  • min_feature_count (int) – The minimum number of examples a feature must have a nonzero value in to be included.
cross_validate(examples, stratified=True, cv_folds=10, grid_search=False, grid_search_folds=5, grid_jobs=None, grid_objective=<function f1_score_micro at 0x2bd5848>, prediction_prefix=None, param_grid=None, shuffle=True)¶

Cross-validates a given model on the training examples.

Parameters:
  • examples (ExamplesTuple) – The data to cross-validate learner performance on.
  • stratified (bool) – Should we stratify the folds to ensure an even distribution of classes for each fold?
  • cv_folds (int or dict) – The number of folds to use for cross-validation, or a mapping from example IDs to folds.
  • grid_search (bool) – Should we do grid search when training each fold? Note: This will make this take much longer.
  • grid_search_folds (int) – The number of folds to use when doing the grid search (ignored if cv_folds is set to a dictionary mapping examples to folds).
  • grid_jobs (int) – The number of jobs to run in parallel when doing the grid search. If unspecified or None, the number of grid search folds will be used.
  • grid_objective (function) – The objective function to use when doing the grid search.
  • param_grid (list of dicts mapping from basestrings to lists of parameter values) – The parameter grid to search through for grid search. If unspecified, a default parameter grid will be used.
  • prediction_prefix (basestring) – If saving the predictions, this is the prefix that will be used for the filename. It will be followed by ”.predictions”
  • shuffle (bool) – Shuffle examples before splitting into folds for CV.
Returns:

The confusion matrix, overall accuracy, per-class PRFs, and model parameters for each fold.
Return type:

list of 4-tuples
evaluate(examples, prediction_prefix=None, append=False, grid_objective=None)¶

Evaluates a given model on a given dev or test example set.

Parameters:
  • examples (ExamplesTuple) – The examples to evaluate the performance of the model on.
  • prediction_prefix (basestring) – If saving the predictions, this is the prefix that will be used for the filename. It will be followed by ”.predictions”
  • append (bool) – Should we append the current predictions to the file if it exists?
  • grid_objective (function) – The objective function that was used when doing the grid search.
Returns:

The confusion matrix, the overall accuracy, the per-class PRFs, the model parameters, and the grid search objective function score.
Return type:

3-tuple
classmethod from_file(learner_path)¶
Returns:New instance of Learner from the pickle at the specified path.
load(learner_path)¶

Replace the current learner instance with a saved learner.

Parameters:learner_path (basestring) – The path to the file to load.
model¶

The underlying scikit-learn model

model_kwargs¶

A dictionary of the underlying scikit-learn model’s keyword arguments

model_params¶

Model parameters (i.e., weights) for ridge regression and liblinear models.

model_type¶

A string representation of the underlying modeltype

predict(examples, prediction_prefix=None, append=False, class_labels=False)¶

Uses a given model to generate predictions on a given data set

Parameters:
  • examples (ExamplesTuple) – The examples to predict the classes for.
  • prediction_prefix (basestring) – If saving the predictions, this is the prefix that will be used for the filename. It will be followed by ”.predictions”
  • append (bool) – Should we append the current predictions to the file if it exists?
  • class_labels (bool) – For classifier, should we convert class indices to their (str) labels?
Returns:

The predictions returned by the learner.
Return type:

array
save(learner_path)¶

Save the learner to a file.

Parameters:learner_path (basestring) – The path to where you want to save the learner.
train(examples, param_grid=None, grid_search_folds=5, grid_search=True, grid_objective=<function f1_score_micro at 0x2bd5848>, grid_jobs=None, shuffle=True)¶

Train a classification model and return the model, score, feature vectorizer, scaler, label dictionary, and inverse label dictionary.

Parameters:
  • examples (ExamplesTuple) – The examples to train the model on.
  • param_grid (list of dicts mapping from basestrings to lists of parameter values) – The parameter grid to search through for grid search. If unspecified, a default parameter grid will be used.
  • grid_search_folds (int or dict) – The number of folds to use when doing the grid search, or a mapping from example IDs to folds.
  • grid_search (bool) – Should we do grid search?
  • grid_objective (function) – The objective function to use when doing the grid search.
  • grid_jobs (int) – The number of jobs to run in parallel when doing the grid search. If unspecified or None, the number of grid search folds will be used.
  • shuffle (bool) – Shuffle examples (e.g., for grid search CV.)
Returns:

The best grid search objective function score, or 0 if we’re not doing grid search.
Return type:

float
skll.__init__.load_examples(path, has_labels=True, sparse=True, quiet=False)¶

Loads examples in the TSV, JSONLINES (a json dict per line), or MegaM formats.

If you would like to include example/instance IDs in your files, they must be specified in the following ways:

  • MegaM: As a comment line directly preceding the line with feature values.
  • TSV: An “id” column.
  • JSONLINES: An “id” key in each JSON dictionary.
Parameters:
  • path (basestring) – The path to the file to load the examples from.
  • has_labels (bool) – Whether or not the file contains class labels.
  • sparse (bool) – Whether or not to store the features in a numpy CSR matrix.
  • quiet (bool) – Do not print “Loading...” status message to stderr.
Returns:

4-tuple of an array example ids, an array of class labels, a scipy CSR matrix of features, and a DictVectorizer containing the mapping between feature names and the column indices in the feature matrix.
skll.__init__.quadratic_weighted_kappa(y_true, y_pred)¶

Returns the quadratic weighted kappa. This rounds the inputs before passing them to the ml_metrics module.

skll.__init__.unweighted_kappa(y_true, y_pred)¶

Returns the unweighted Cohen’s kappa.

skll.__init__.kendall_tau(y_true, y_pred)¶

Optimize the hyperparameter values during the grid search based on Kendall’s tau.

This is useful in cases where you want to use the actual probabilities of the different classes after the fact, and not just the optimize based on the classification accuracy.

skll.__init__.spearman(y_true, y_pred)¶

Optimize the hyperparameter values during the grid search based on Spearman rank correlation.

This is useful in cases where you want to use the actual probabilities of the different classes after the fact, and not just the optimize based on the classification accuracy.

skll.__init__.pearson(y_true, y_pred)¶

Optimize the hyperparameter values during the grid search based on Pearson correlation.

skll.__init__.f1_score_least_frequent(y_true, y_pred)¶

Optimize the hyperparameter values during the grid search based on the F1 measure of the least frequent class.

This is mostly intended for use when you’re doing binary classification and your data is highly skewed. You should probably use f1_score_macro if your data is skewed and you’re doing multi-class classification.

skll.__init__.f1_score_macro(y_true, y_pred)¶

Use the macro-averaged F1 measure to select hyperparameter values during the cross-validation grid search during training.

This method averages over classes (does not take imbalance into account). You should use this if each class is equally important.

skll.__init__.f1_score_micro(y_true, y_pred)¶

Use the micro-averaged F1 measure to select hyperparameter values during the cross-validation grid search during training.

This method averages over instances (takes imbalance into account). This implies that precision == recall == F1.

skll.__init__.accuracy(y_true, y_pred)¶

Use the overall accuracy to select hyperparameter values during the cross- validation grid search during training.

skll.__init__.run_configuration(config_file, local=False, overwrite=True, queue=u'all.q', hosts=None)¶

Takes a configuration file and runs the specified jobs on the grid.

skll.__init__.run_ablation(config_file, local=False, overwrite=True, queue=u'all.q', hosts=None)¶

Takes a configuration file and runs repeated experiments where each feature set has been removed from the configuration.

data Module¶

Handles loading data from various types of data files.

author:Dan Blanchard (dblanchard@ets.org)
author:Michael Heilman (mheilman@ets.org)
author:Nitin Madnani (nmadnani@ets.org)
organization:ETS

Alias for field number 3

Alias for field number 2

Alias for field number 0

skll.data.load_examples(path, has_labels=True, sparse=True, quiet=False)[source]¶

Loads examples in the TSV, JSONLINES (a json dict per line), or MegaM formats.

If you would like to include example/instance IDs in your files, they must be specified in the following ways:

  • MegaM: As a comment line directly preceding the line with feature values.
  • TSV: An “id” column.
  • JSONLINES: An “id” key in each JSON dictionary.
Parameters:
  • path (basestring) – The path to the file to load the examples from.
  • has_labels (bool) – Whether or not the file contains class labels.
  • sparse (bool) – Whether or not to store the features in a numpy CSR matrix.
  • quiet (bool) – Do not print “Loading...” status message to stderr.
Returns:

4-tuple of an array example ids, an array of class labels, a scipy CSR matrix of features, and a DictVectorizer containing the mapping between feature names and the column indices in the feature matrix.

experiments Module¶

Functions related to running experiments and parsing configuration files.

author:Dan Blanchard (dblanchard@ets.org)
author:Michael Heilman (mheilman@ets.org)
author:Nitin Madnani (nmadnani@ets.org)
skll.experiments.run_ablation(config_file, local=False, overwrite=True, queue=u'all.q', hosts=None)[source]¶

Takes a configuration file and runs repeated experiments where each feature set has been removed from the configuration.

skll.experiments.run_configuration(config_file, local=False, overwrite=True, queue=u'all.q', hosts=None)[source]¶

Takes a configuration file and runs the specified jobs on the grid.

learner Module¶

Provides easy-to-use wrapper around scikit-learn.

author:Michael Heilman (mheilman@ets.org)
author:Nitin Madnani (nmadnani@ets.org)
author:Dan Blanchard (dblanchard@ets.org)
organization:ETS
class skll.learner.Learner(probability=False, do_scale_features=False, model_type=u'logistic', model_kwargs=None, pos_label_str=None, use_dense_features=False, min_feature_count=1)[source]¶

Bases: object

A simpler learner interface around many scikit-learn classification and regression functions.

Parameters:
  • do_scale_features (bool) – Should we scale features with this learner?
  • model_type (basestring) – Type of estimator to create. Options are: ‘logistic’, ‘svm_linear’, ‘svm_radial’, ‘naivebayes’, ‘dtree’, ‘rforest’, and ‘gradient’
  • probability (bool) – Should learner return probabilities of all classes (instead of just class with highest probability)?
  • model_kwargs (dict) – A dictionary of keyword arguments to pass to the initializer for the specified model.
  • pos_label_str (str) – The string for the positive class in the binary classification setting. Otherwise, an arbitrary class is picked.
  • use_dense_features (bool) – Whether to require conversion to dense feature matrices.
  • min_feature_count (int) – The minimum number of examples a feature must have a nonzero value in to be included.
cross_validate(examples, stratified=True, cv_folds=10, grid_search=False, grid_search_folds=5, grid_jobs=None, grid_objective=<function f1_score_micro at 0x2bd5848>, prediction_prefix=None, param_grid=None, shuffle=True)[source]¶

Cross-validates a given model on the training examples.

Parameters:
  • examples (ExamplesTuple) – The data to cross-validate learner performance on.
  • stratified (bool) – Should we stratify the folds to ensure an even distribution of classes for each fold?
  • cv_folds (int or dict) – The number of folds to use for cross-validation, or a mapping from example IDs to folds.
  • grid_search (bool) – Should we do grid search when training each fold? Note: This will make this take much longer.
  • grid_search_folds (int) – The number of folds to use when doing the grid search (ignored if cv_folds is set to a dictionary mapping examples to folds).
  • grid_jobs (int) – The number of jobs to run in parallel when doing the grid search. If unspecified or None, the number of grid search folds will be used.
  • grid_objective (function) – The objective function to use when doing the grid search.
  • param_grid (list of dicts mapping from basestrings to lists of parameter values) – The parameter grid to search through for grid search. If unspecified, a default parameter grid will be used.
  • prediction_prefix (basestring) – If saving the predictions, this is the prefix that will be used for the filename. It will be followed by ”.predictions”
  • shuffle (bool) – Shuffle examples before splitting into folds for CV.
Returns:

The confusion matrix, overall accuracy, per-class PRFs, and model parameters for each fold.
Return type:

list of 4-tuples

Train a classification model and return the model, score, feature vectorizer, scaler, label dictionary, and inverse label dictionary.

Parameters:
  • examples (ExamplesTuple) – The examples to train the model on.
  • param_grid (list of dicts mapping from basestrings to lists of parameter values) – The parameter grid to search through for grid search. If unspecified, a default parameter grid will be used.
  • grid_search_folds (int or dict) – The number of folds to use when doing the grid search, or a mapping from example IDs to folds.
  • grid_search (bool) – Should we do grid search?
  • grid_objective (function) – The objective function to use when doing the grid search.
  • grid_jobs (int) – The number of jobs to run in parallel when doing the grid search. If unspecified or None, the number of grid search folds will be used.
  • shuffle (bool) – Shuffle examples (e.g., for grid search CV.)
Returns:

The best grid search objective function score, or 0 if we’re not doing grid search.
Return type:

float
class skll.learner.RescaledRegressionMixin[source]¶

Bases: sklearn.base.BaseEstimator

Mixin to create regressors that store a min and a max for the training data and make sure that predictions fall within that range. It also stores the means and SDs of the gold standard and the predictions on the training set to rescale the predictions (e.g., as in e-rater).

rescale_fit(X, y=None)[source]¶

Fit a model, then store the mean, SD, max and min of the training set and the mean and SD of the predictions on the training set.

rescale_get_param_names()[source]¶

This is adapted from scikit-learns’s BaseEstimator class. It gets the kwargs for the superclass’s init method and adds the kwargs for the rescale_init method.

rescale_init(constrain=True, rescale=True, **kwargs)[source]¶
rescale_predict(X)[source]¶

Make predictions with the super class, and then adjust them using the stored min, max, means, and standard deviations.

class skll.learner.RescaledRidge(constrain=True, rescale=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: sklearn.linear_model.ridge.Ridge, skll.learner.RescaledRegressionMixin

fit(X, y=None)[source]¶
predict(X)[source]¶
class skll.learner.RescaledSVR(constrain=True, rescale=True, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: sklearn.svm.classes.SVR, skll.learner.RescaledRegressionMixin

fit(X, y=None)[source]¶
predict(X)[source]¶
class skll.learner.SelectByMinCount(min_count=1)[source]¶

Bases: sklearn.feature_selection.univariate_selection.SelectKBest

Select features ocurring in more (and/or fewer than) than a specified number of examples in the training data (or a CV training fold).

fit(X, y=None)[source]¶

metrics Module¶

This module contains a bunch of evaluation metrics that can be used to evaluate the performance of learners.

author:Michael Heilman (mheilman@ets.org)
author:Nitin Madnani (nmadnani@ets.org)
author:Dan Blanchard (dblanchard@ets.org)
organization:ETS
skll.metrics.accuracy(y_true, y_pred)[source]¶

Use the overall accuracy to select hyperparameter values during the cross- validation grid search during training.

skll.metrics.f1_score_least_frequent(y_true, y_pred)[source]¶

Optimize the hyperparameter values during the grid search based on the F1 measure of the least frequent class.

This is mostly intended for use when you’re doing binary classification and your data is highly skewed. You should probably use f1_score_macro if your data is skewed and you’re doing multi-class classification.

skll.metrics.f1_score_macro(y_true, y_pred)[source]¶

Use the macro-averaged F1 measure to select hyperparameter values during the cross-validation grid search during training.

This method averages over classes (does not take imbalance into account). You should use this if each class is equally important.

skll.metrics.f1_score_micro(y_true, y_pred)[source]¶

Use the micro-averaged F1 measure to select hyperparameter values during the cross-validation grid search during training.

This method averages over instances (takes imbalance into account). This implies that precision == recall == F1.

skll.metrics.kendall_tau(y_true, y_pred)[source]¶

Optimize the hyperparameter values during the grid search based on Kendall’s tau.

This is useful in cases where you want to use the actual probabilities of the different classes after the fact, and not just the optimize based on the classification accuracy.

skll.metrics.pearson(y_true, y_pred)[source]¶

Optimize the hyperparameter values during the grid search based on Pearson correlation.

skll.metrics.quadratic_weighted_kappa(y_true, y_pred)[source]¶

Returns the quadratic weighted kappa. This rounds the inputs before passing them to the ml_metrics module.

skll.metrics.spearman(y_true, y_pred)[source]¶

Optimize the hyperparameter values during the grid search based on Spearman rank correlation.

This is useful in cases where you want to use the actual probabilities of the different classes after the fact, and not just the optimize based on the classification accuracy.

skll.metrics.unweighted_kappa(y_true, y_pred)[source]¶

Returns the unweighted Cohen’s kappa.
